title: Protocol for in vivo and ex vivo assessment of hyperglycemia and islet function in diabetic mice
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
This protocol allows studies of islet proliferation, apoptosis, programming, and insulin secretion including GTT, ITT, and GSIS in vivo and histological and flow cytometry analyses ex vivo.
Glucose tolerance test
Timing: 8 h
This section describes how to measure the fasting blood glucose level from tail veins at different time point after D-glucose injection.
Fast mice for 6 h with free to access autoclaved water.
Prepare 0.05 g/mL glucose solution in saline.
Label the mice with ear tag or marker pen.
Scale mice body weight and measure the fasting blood glucose level from tail veins using a blood glucose meter in sequence.
Calculate the D-glucose volume (1 g/kg bodyweight) for each mouse according to the body weight.
I.p. inject D-glucose to mice in sequence and start timing.
Measure blood glucose level at 15, 30, 45, 60, 90, and 120 min after injection.
Insulin tolerance test
Timing: 8 h
This section describes how to measure the fasting blood glucose level from tail veins at different time point after insulin injection.
Fast mice for 6 h with free to access autoclaved water.
Dilute insulin solution in saline for 100× to 0.8 U/mL.
Label mice with ear tag or marker pen.
Scale mice body weight and measure the fasting blood glucose level from tail veins using a blood glucose meter in sequence.
Calculate the insulin volume (1.5 U/kg bodyweight) for each mouse according to the body weight.
I.p. inject insulin to mice in sequence and start timing.
Measure blood glucose level at 15, 30, 45, 60, 90, and 120 min after injection.
Note: We recommended a prior test to confirm whether the mice are insulin sensitive with a lower insulin dose at 0.5–1 U/kg.
Glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS) assay
Timing: 24 h

This section describes how to measure the fasting blood insulin level from tail veins at different time point after D-glucose injection. Refer to troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5].
Fast mice for 6 h with free to access autoclaved water.
Prepare 0.15 g/mL glucose solution in saline to increase plasma insulin level rapidly.
Label the mice with ear tag or marker pen.
Scale mice body weight and calculate the D-glucose volume (3 g/kg bodyweight) for each mouse according to the body weight.
I.p. inject D-glucose to mice in sequence and start timing.
Measure blood glucose level and collect blood samples from tail-tip bleeding at 0, 2, 5, and 15 min (first phase insulin secretion) after glucose injection.
Centrifuge the blood by 5,000 × g for 15 min at 4°C, collect the plasma, and store at −80°C for later use.
Determine plasma insulin levels by insulin ultra-sensitive kit according to the manufacturer’s instruction (https://www.crystalchem.com/media/catalog/product/9/0/90080c.pdf[href=https://www.crystalchem.com/media/catalog/product/9/0/90080c.pdf]).
Pause point: If measurements of insulin level will be done on another day, store plasma at −80°C.
Critical: Pancreatic β-cells secrete insulin in a biphasic manner at first and second phase. First phase insulin secretion occurs within 10 min of glucose stimulation, while second phase insulin secretion is occurring 25–30 min after glucose stimulation. Loss of first phase insulin secretion is an independent predictor of T2D onset. Don't collect blood samples from tail-tip bleeding more than 15 min after glucose injection.7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]
Pancreas histologic analysis for islet number and insulin expression
Timing: 5 days
This section describes how to perform histologic analysis for islet function by measuring insulin expression, total islet number, and islet size distribution in pancreas. Refer to troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7].
Collect mouse pancreas tissues without saline perfusion.
Fix pancreas tissues in 10% neutral phosphate buffered formalin for 24 h at room temperature (22°C).

Dehydrate pancreas tissues through graded increasing ethanol (50, 70, 95, and 100%) 2 h each at room temperature (22°C), acetone, and chloroform 30 min each at 60°C.
Embed pancreas tissues in paraffin.
Slice serial pancreatic sections at 6 μm in thickness and place on histological glass slide.
Deparaffinize pancreatic paraffin sections in xylene at room temperature (22°C).
Rehydrate sections in a graded decreasing ethanol series (100, 95, 70, and 50%) 5 min each and then in water for 5 min at room temperature (22°C).
Block sections with 5% normal goat serum for 30 min.
Incubate sections with rabbit anti-insulin in 1:500 overnight (8 h) at 4°C.
Incubate sections with biotin-conjugated goat anti-rabbit in 1:200 for 45 min at room temperature (22°C).
Incubate sections with HRP-streptavidin in 1:500 for 30 min at room temperature (22°C).
Detect insulin positive area with AEC chromogenic agent for 1 min at room temperature (22°C).
Counterstain slides with hematoxylin for 10 s at room temperature (22°C).
Scan whole pancreatic tissue sections with the Olympus VS120 Whole Slide Scanner.
Detect insulin staining intensity with Image-Pro Plus and present as positive area.
Quantify total islet number per pancreas.
Quantify each islet area in μm2 by identifying islet area with Image-Pro Plus and calculating with scale bar in whole section picture.
Quantify islet numbers of different size groups including <1,000 μm2/islet, 1,000–5,000 μm2/islet, 5,000–15,000 μm2/islet, >15,000 μm2/islet.
Pause point: If the staining of insulin will be done on another day, put the pancreatic paraffin slide storage box and store it at room temperature (22°C).
Note: Xylene or toluene are also accessible methods for paraffin embedding of the pancreas and can be used to replace acetone and chloroform.
Islet insulin secretion assay ex vivo
Timing: 36 h

This section describes how to measure insulin secretion at different time point after D-glucose stimulation in cultured islets.
Hand-pick up 25 similar size islets from each group and culture islets in RPMI 1640 medium with 10% FBS overnight (8 h) after isolation.
Culture islets in medium containing 2.8 mM (low glucose) or 16.7 mM (high glucose) glucose for 0.5, 1, or 1.5 h.
Collect culture medium from each group.
Determine media insulin levels by insulin ultra-sensitive kit according to the manufacturer’s instruction (https://www.crystalchem.com/media/catalog/product/9/0/90080c.pdf[href=https://www.crystalchem.com/media/catalog/product/9/0/90080c.pdf]) and normalize to per mg of islets protein.
Pause point: If measurements of insulin level will be done on another day, store media and islets at −80°C.
Ki67 expression for islet proliferation assay ex vivo
Timing: 60 h
This section describes how to measure islet proliferation by immunofluorescent co-localization staining. Refer to troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9].
Hand-pick up 40 similar size islets from each group and culture islets in RPMI 1640 medium with 10% FBS overnight (8 h) after isolation.
Culture islets in medium containing 16.7 mM glucose for 24 h.
Centrifuge and resuspend islets in 200 μL PBS.
Place slides and filters into slots with the cardboard filters appropriately.
Quickly move 200 μL of each sample into the appropriate wells of the cytospin.
Cytospin each group of islets to slides by 2,000 rpm for 5 min.
Remove the filters from their slides carefully and wait for air dry.
Fix slides with cold acetone for 5 min.
Wash slides in PBS for 3 times after air dry.
Block islet sections with 5% normal goat serum for 30 min.
Immunofluorescent co-localization stain islet sections with 5% normal goat serum containing rabbit anti-Ki67 (1:100) and rat anti-insulin (1:500) antibodies overnight (8 h) at 4°C.
Wash slides in PBS for 3 times.

Incubate sections in 5% normal goat serum containing Alex Fluor 555-labeled goat anti-rabbit (1:300) and Alex Fluor 488-labeled donkey anti-rat (1:500) secondary antibodies for 30 min.
Wash slides in PBS for 3 times.
Incubate sections in 0.4 μM DAPI for 10 min and cover slide with coverslips in mounting medium.
Capture images with Olympus confocal microscopy.
Pause point: If the staining of Ki67 will be done on another day, store the slide at −80°C after fixation.
Flow cytometry detection of BrdU pulse labeling for islet proliferation assay
Timing: 60 h
This section describes how to detect islet proliferation by flow cytometry staining of freshly prepared islets cell after BrdU pulse.
Hand-pick up 40 similar size islets from each group and culture islets in RPMI 1640 medium with 10% FBS overnight (8 h) after isolation.
Pulse isolated WT islets with 5 μg/mL BrdU for 2 h.
Disperse islets with 1 mL fresh accutase for 10 min at 37°C incubator with 5% CO2.
Wash islet cells in PBS once.
Block islet cells with Fc block (1:100) in FACS buffer for 20 min.
Wash islet cells in PBS once.
Label islet cells with Alexa Fluor 647 anti-insulin (1 μg/mL) and FITC anti-BrdU (1 μg/mL) or isotypes for 30 min in intracellular staining buffer according to the manufacturer’s instruction (https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.cn/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2F88-8823.pdf[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.cn/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2F88-8823.pdf]).
Flow cytometry analysis using a FACS Analyzer LSR Fortessa (BD Biosciences) or other Flow Cytometer.
Immunofluorescent staining detection of BrdU pulse labeling for islet proliferation assay
Timing: 60 h
This section describes how to measure islet proliferation by immunofluorescent co-localization staining after BrdU pulse.
Hand-pick up 40 similar size islets from each group and culture islets in RPMI 1640 medium with 10% FBS overnight (8 h) after isolation.
Pulse isolated WT islets with 5 μg/mL BrdU for 2 h.

Cytospin each group of islets to slides following the steps 47–51.
Wash, fix, and block sections following the steps 52–54.
Immunofluorescent co-localization stain islet sections with 5% normal goat serum containing mouse anti-BrdU (1:100) and rat anti-insulin (1:500) antibodies overnight (8 h) at 4°C.
Wash slides in PBS for 3 times.
Incubate sections in 5% normal goat serum containing Alex Fluor 555-labeled goat anti-mouse (1:300) and Alex Fluor 488-labeled donkey anti-rat (1:500) secondary antibodies for 30 min.
Wash and cover slides, and capture images following the steps 58–60.
Pause point: If the staining of BrdU will be done on another day, store the slide at −80°C after fixation.
STZ-induced apoptosis assay in vitro
Timing: 60 h
This section describes how to measure STZ-induced islets apoptosis by immunofluorescent co-localization staining.
Hand-pick up 40 similar size islets from each group and culture islets in RPMI 1640 medium with 10% FBS overnight (8 h) after isolation at 37°C incubator.
Stimulate islets with 50 mM STZ for 30 min.
Cytospin each group of islets to slides following the steps 47–51.
Wash, fix, and block sections following the steps 52–54.
Immunofluorescent co-localization stain islet sections with 5% normal goat serum containing rabbit anti-Cleaved caspase 3 (1:200) and rat anti-insulin (1:500) antibodies overnight (8 h) at 4°C.
Wash slides in PBS for 3 times.
Incubate sections in 5% normal goat serum containing Alex Fluor 555-labeled goat anti-rabbit (1:300) and Alex Fluor 488-labeled donkey anti-rat (1:500) secondary antibodies for 30 min at room temperature (22°C).
Wash and cover slides, and capture images following the steps 58–60.
Pause point: If the staining of Cleaved caspase 3 will be done on another day, store the slide at −80°C after fixation.
Flow cytometry detection of islet β-cell programming assay
Timing: 4 days

This section describes how to detect islet β-cell programming by flow cytometry staining of freshly prepared islets cell.
Hand-pick up 40 similar size islets from each group and culture islets in RPMI 1640 medium with 10% FBS overnight (8 h) after isolation.
Culture islets in medium containing 50 μM adenosine dialdehyde (Adox) for 72 h at 37°C incubator with 5% CO2.
Disperse, wash, and block islets cells following the steps 63–66.
Stain islets with Alexa Fluor 647 anti-insulin (1 μg/mL) and PE anti-glucagon (1 μg/mL) or isotypes for 30 min at 4°C with intracellular staining buffer according to the manufacturer’s instructions (https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.cn/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2F88-8823.pdf[href=https://www.thermofisher.com/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.cn/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2F88-8823.pdf]).
Flow cytometry analysis using a FACS Analyzer LSR.
Quantify Glucagon+, Ins+, and Glucagon+Ins+cells in each group of islets.
Immunofluorescent staining detection of Islet β-cell programming assay
Timing: 5 days
This section describes how to detect islet β-cell programming by immunofluorescent co-localization staining.
Hand-pick up 40 similar size islets from each group and culture islets in RPMI 1640 medium with 10% FBS overnight (8 h) after isolation.
Culture islets in medium containing 50 μM adenosine dialdehyde (Adox) for 72 h at 37°C incubator with 5% CO2.
Cytospin each group of islets to slides following the steps 47–51.
Wash, fix, and block sections following the steps 52–54.
Immunofluorescent co-localization stain islet sections with 5% normal goat serum containing mouse anti-Glucagon (1:200) and rat anti-insulin (1:500) antibodies overnight (8 h) at 4°C.
Wash slides in PBS for 3 times.
Incubate sections in 5% normal goat serum containing Alex Fluor 555-labeled goat anti-mouse (1:300) and Alex Fluor 488-labeled donkey anti-rat (1:500) secondary antibodies for 30 min.
Wash and cover slides, and capture images following the steps 58–60.
Pause point: If the staining will be done on another day, store the slide at −80°C after fixation.
